trial_identification.studytitle: Evaluation of the Effectiveness of LASER Acupuncture on Osteo Arthritic Knee (OAK) Pain: A Randomised, Double Blind, Placebo-controlled Clinical Trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Evaluation of the Effectiveness of LASER Acupuncture on Osteo Arthritic Knee (OAK) Pain: A Randomised, Double Blind, Placebo-controlled Clinical Trial

interventions.interventions: An 810nm Class 3B diode LASER with an output of 100mW is irradiate acupuncture points most commonly used to treat osteoartshritis knee pain 3 times a week for 4 weeks (12 treatments, each of 45 minutes duration). Additional acupoints for sub-categories of Phlegm Retention Syndrome and Blood Stasis are used as required.
interventions.comparator: For the control group, an inactive LASER is used on the same acupuncture points as those irradiated in the intervention group.

primaryOutcome.outcome: WOMAC - to assess osteoarthritis knee symptoms
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Before and after 12 treatments and at 1 month and 2 months follow-up
Before and after each of treatment and at 1 month and 2 months follow-up

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before and after 12 treatments and at 1 month and 2 months follow-up
Before and after 12 treatments and at 1 month and 2 months follow-up

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Multi Dimensional Health Locus of Control - Form C (MHLC-C)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before and after 12 treatments and at 1 month and 2 months follow-up
Before and after 12 treatments and at 1 month and 2 months follow-up
Before and after 12 treatments and at 1 month and 2 months follow-up

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Adults. 2. Meet Western and Traditional Chinese Medicine diagnostic criteria for osteoarthritis knee pain. 3. Have no other serious health condition. 4. Have suffered osteo arthritic knee (OAK) condition for less than 10 years. 5. Have no history of receiving LASER acupuncture treatment for OAK.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Do not fit inclusion criteria 2. Suffering other medical conditions, e.g. multiple sclerosis, diabetes, asthma, dementia, kidney disease, etc 3. Photo (light) sensitivity or on medication that increases photo sensitivity 4. Extensive impaired mobility that would make participation difficult 5. Cognitive abilities that may prevent understanding of study protocols and processes

trial_design.concealment: 1. Participants assessed in both Western medicine and Chinese medicine terms. 2. Diagnosed by treating medial practitioner/specialist as suffering from osteoarthritis knee (OAK) pain and graded ats Kellgren-Lawrence Grade 2-3. 3. Assessed by TCM practitioner to ensure OAK syndrome is diagnosed according to most common TCM pattern of Bi Syndrome with sub-patterns of Phlegm Retention in Joints and Blood Stasis in Joints. 4. Participants randomly allocated to treatment or placebo groups via opaque envelopes.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table created by computer software (i.e. computerised sequence generation).
trial_design.statisticalmethods: ANOVA and t tests to measure statistical significance

othercollaborator.othercollaboratorname: Meikin Li Rees University of Technology, Sydney

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The study tests the effectiveness of LASER acupuncture on osteo arthritis knee (OAK) pain. OAK is the most common form of arthritis. OAK sufferers and LASER and acupuncture practitioners would benefit from the study in a number of ways. For example, a positive outcome: 1. Would determine an effective LASER acupuncture treatment protocol and influence clinical practice. 2. May help reduce dependency on pharmacological treatments and alleviate associated drug side effects. 3. May reduce the cost and/or financial burden of OA treatment for individuals and the community as a whole. 4. Would help increase awareness about the choice of available treatments.
A negative study outcome: 1. May prove the null hypothesis correct (i.e. LASER acupuncture is not effective for OAK). 2. Would encourage further investigations to test the validity of the study design or develop new experiments.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Preliminary results presented at Laser Helsinki International Congress held in Helsinki, Finland, from 24-29 August 2012.
